title: Workshop Resources
text:
Software & Tools

Required Software






TipEssential Tools for Day 1




R Statistical Software
üì• Download R
RStudio IDE
üì• Download RStudio
DAGitty (Web-based)
üåê Access DAGitty
No installation needed - runs in your browser!





R Package Installation
Copy and run this code in RStudio to install all required packages:
# core packages
install.packages(c(
  "tidyverse",      # data manipulation and visualisation
  "dagitty",        # dag analysis
  "ggdag",          # dag visualisation
  "broom",          # tidy model outputs
  "kableExtra",     # nice tables
  "flextable"       # flexible tables
))

# additional useful packages
install.packages(c(
  "lmtest",         # linear model tests
  "sandwich",       # robust standard errors
  "marginaleffects", # marginal effects
  "MatchIt",        # matching methods
  "WeightIt"        # weighting methods
))

title: Workshop Resources
text:
Quick Reference Guides

Causal Diagram Notation


DAG Symbol Guide

‚Üí Direct causal effect
‚óã Unobserved/latent variable
‚ñ° Observed variable
‚Üê‚Üí Bidirectional relationship
- - Non-causal association



Common Structures

Confounder: X ‚Üê Z ‚Üí Y
Mediator: X ‚Üí M ‚Üí Y
Collider: X ‚Üí C ‚Üê Y
Instrument: Z ‚Üí X ‚Üí Y





EESI Workflow






NoteThe EESI Framework




Estimand: What causal quantity do we want?
Estimator: How will we estimate it?
Estimate: What is our numerical result?
Simulation: How do we validate our approach?

We‚Äôll practice this framework throughout the workshop!

title: Workshop Resources
text:
Code Templates

Basic DAG in R
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

# create a simple dag
dag <- dagitty('dag {
  Religion -> Cooperation
  SES -> Religion
  SES -> Cooperation
}')

# visualise
ggdag(dag) + theme_dag()

# identify adjustment sets
adjustmentSets(dag, exposure = "Religion", outcome = "Cooperation")


Simulation Template
# simulate confounded relationship
set.seed(123)
n <- 1000

# confounders
ses <- rnorm(n)

# treatment (religion)
religion <- rbinom(n, 1, plogis(0.5 * ses))

# outcome (cooperation)
cooperation <- 2 + 0.5 * religion + 0.3 * ses + rnorm(n)

# naive estimate (biased)
lm(cooperation ~ religion)

# adjusted estimate (unbiased)
lm(cooperation ~ religion + ses)

title: The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide to Cause and Effect
text:
Building Foundations for Causal Thinking in the Study of Religion and Cooperation
Tuesday, 12 August 2025 | 09:00 ‚Äì 17:00

title: The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide to Cause and Effect
text:
Workshop Overview
This workshop introduces the fundamental concepts and practical skills for causal inference in observational data. We‚Äôll explore how to move beyond correlation to understand causation in the study of religion and cooperation.

title: The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide to Cause and Effect
text:
Schedule




Table¬†1: Day 1 Workshop Schedule






Time
Session
Learning Goals & Activities




09:00‚Äì09:30
Welcome & Introduction
**Goal:** Frame causal inference as a structured framework for inquiry. We will outline the day's agenda and introduce core skills for causal thinking. **Activity:** Discussion of typical causal questions in the study of religion and cooperation.


09:30‚Äì10:35
Basic Theory of Causality
**Goal:** Cultivate skills in counterfactual thinking by introducing the potential outcomes framework. We will cover the intellectual history and the fundamental problem of causal inference. **Example:** Initial discussion of estimands, estimators, and estimates.


10:35‚Äì10:50
Morning Tea



10:50‚Äì12:30
Simulation-Based Inference
**Goal:** Understand your causal system through simulation. Introduction to the EESI (Estimand, Estimator, Estimate, Simulation) workflow for organising projects. **Activity:** A worked example of simulation-based inference, followed by group discussion.


12:30‚Äì13:30
Lunch



13:30‚Äì15:00
Mapping Causal Systems (DAGs)
**Goal:** Learn techniques for drawing and simulating causal systems using Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs). Understand how to use theory, common sense, and metadata to build a DAG. **Activity:** Workshop on identifying confounds, colliders, instruments, and other biases. Introduction to `DAGitty` and simulations in `R`.


15:00‚Äì15:15
Afternoon Tea



15:15‚Äì16:00
Controlling for Variables
**Goal:** Develop a sense of which variables to worry about in causal inference. Distinguish between 'good,' 'bad,' and 'inconsequential' controls. **Activity:** Group exercises on evaluating control variables in example causal diagrams.


16:00‚Äì16:45
Estimating Causal Effects
**Goal:** Learn introductory approaches to estimating causal effects. **Activity:** Overview of g-computation, inverse probability weighting (IPW), and doubly robust estimation. Discussion of sensitivity checks.


16:45‚Äì17:00
Wrap-up & Discussion
**Goal:** Consolidate the day's concepts. **Activity:** Q&A and open discussion about applying these methods to participants' work.

title: The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide to Cause and Effect
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of Day 1, participants will be able to:

üéØ Core Skills

Think causally about correlations in observational data
Draw and interpret causal diagrams (DAGs)
Identify confounders, colliders, and other sources of bias
Apply the EESI workflow to structure research projects
Select appropriate control variables for causal analyses
Understand basic estimation approaches (g-computation, IPW, doubly robust methods)

title: The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide to Cause and Effect
text:
What You‚Äôll Need






TipPrerequisites




Basic familiarity with statistical concepts (regression, correlation)
Interest in causal questions about religion and cooperation
No prior causal inference experience required!









NoteMaterials to Bring




Laptop with R and RStudio installed (optional but helpful)
Your research questions about religion and cooperation
Enthusiasm for collaborative learning!

title: The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide to Cause and Effect
text:
Workshop Philosophy
This workshop emphasizes learning by doing. We‚Äôll work through practical examples, engage in group exercises, and apply concepts to real research questions in the study of religion and cooperation.

‚ÄúCorrelation does not imply causation, but it sure is a hint!‚Äù

title: Pre-Workshop Reading
text: Get the most out of Day 1 by reviewing these foundational materials

title: Pre-Workshop Reading
text:
Required Reading
The following readings are recommended in descending order of importance for the workshop:

1. Thinking Clearly About Correlations and Causation

Rohrer, J. M. (2018). Thinking clearly about correlations and causation: Graphical causal models for observational data. Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science, 1(1), 27-42.
üìñ https://doi.org/10.1177/2515245917745629
Why this matters: This paper provides an excellent introduction to causal diagrams (DAGs) and how they help us think about causation in observational data. Essential reading for understanding the core concepts we‚Äôll use throughout the workshop.



2. Causality in the Study of Religion

Major-Smith, D. (2023). Exploring causality from observational data: An example assessing whether religiosity promotes cooperation. Evolutionary Human Sciences, 5, e22.
üìñ https://doi.org/10.1017/ehs.2023.17
Why this matters: A practical application of causal inference methods to a key question in the study of religion. This paper demonstrates the workflow we‚Äôll be learning.



3. The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide (Chapters 1-4)

Bendixen, T, and Purzycki, B. G. (forthcoming). The Data Analyst‚Äôs Guide to Cause and Effect. London: SAGE.
üìö Chapters 1-4 (Day 1 will largely follow Chapters 1-2)
Why this matters: Our primary textbook for the workshop. These chapters introduce the fundamental concepts and practical approaches we‚Äôll be using.
Note: Materials will be provided to workshop participants.

R Resources
If you plan to follow along with the code examples, please ensure you have R and RStudio installed:

Installation Guide


Install R (version 4.0 or higher)
Download from: https://cran.r-project.org/
Install RStudio
Download from: https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Install Required Packages
Run this code in RStudio:
install.packages(c(
  "tidyverse",
  "dagitty",
  "ggdag",
  "broom",
  "margot",
  "kableExtra"
))

title: Pre-Workshop Reading
text:
Conceptual Foundations

Key Concepts to Review
Before the workshop, it will be helpful to be familiar with these statistical concepts:


Basic Statistics

Correlation vs Causation
Regression analysis basics
Confounding variables
Selection bias



Research Design

Observational vs Experimental data
Counterfactual thinking
Treatment and control groups

title: Pre-Workshop Reading
text:
Questions to Consider
As you read, consider these questions about your own research:

‚ú® What causal questions about religion and cooperation interest you?


What is your outcome of interest?
What is your treatment or exposure?
What confounders might bias your analysis?
What data would you need to answer your question?
How would you communicate your findings?
